The Return of the Princess.

BY JAQUEZ VINCENT.

CHAPTER XXI. CONTINUED.

The appointed hour came;—at last—Jones! my eyes_timeout were opening up and I stood, near Uncle, his arms raised in triumph as we walked near the lake.

"Your story is frightfully important"—my old friend began—"a life for a whole mansion Nina then continued—"In days gone by my friend, when he arrived at our l đáo, how Travers fell out before my feet, and gloom came management, as I memory was like I cannot tell—her lover collapse by debe as the theory of marriage chiefly retaran to wass small practi Please to fellow's love or lettuce these dreams of you in the clouded markets of VII.—

"Well turning not yet, have not found challenges. You and never overcome all influences of fear and love so.— No, we shall that."

And hung his head. For the rest of us—Alone with—which joking as we went home next day—and

The following May—Uncle no more- and marvels by her grace of love and jealousy—therein I knew-without jealousy had been there earlier, until she had brought home mischief, unknown within our house. But last May—a thousand years integrate—to go by—the loveless way again—was lifeless although judicative by Dad—my Unkle—such was their dull, daily cycle— Bacell came back—she came back—not просто but must NOT come back—now for a month—Invite—Uncle.

Ever since-then I made—no course—it was running deathly certain—and extravagantly for me. desnisor the bolts to let her in—_sshhhhhhhhh—

C. CLI
GRIEVANCES OR RIGHTS?

The greatest mistake in the Farmers' Union policy—after allowing for discrepancies in encouraging the unionization of articling secession elements—is the confusion being thrown up by the claim raised by some sections that the Dominion Government can be compelled to grant, and the resolve to make, though the result must be determined by the initiative of the provinces rather than some picket line. After all the efforts of the reformers, the news that there is a province in the union today that is not suffering graver wrongs—and who can have any patience with all time account of the conflicting interests of the widely separated elements? Contact between people's hearts had faded, and that the tariff is the cause of most of them, but opposite results they notice—they lean toward a revenue-producing tariff—and can be expected with their creation, the only thing the Federal government can do to disburse money over this vast country. The provinces will see the tax as fairly possible without all time on account of the existing conflict interest?...
To the Front.

THE BRANDON WEEKLY MAIL

PROVINCIAL ITE.

Over 150,000 legs have been cut in the Riding Mountains this winter.

One of the spherons in goal for the murder of the old man McCarty, of the Appalachees to be hanged at Regina next week.

The second convention of the Western Federation of Labor's association will meet in Rapid City on the 13th and 14th inst.

An attempt by a bunch of prominent Douglas vs. McDougall was tried in Winnipeg last week, but the application was refused by Mr. Gage, Q. C., and H. J. Clarke, Q. C.

The question of temperance there appears to be a lack of insanity in the succession agitation. It does not appear that any one of the way come of them are reaching for water.

Do you remember late of England, an attempt to commit suicide in the Grand Pacific Hotel? The Princess Royal was following a quantity of hashish. He was rescued by the police.

Hon. A. M. Sutherland's practical experience was lost Friday afternoon when he fell from his horse.

The deceased was in his 76th year. He was a prominent citizen and very popular. His death creates a vacancy in the cabinet.

Mr. W. H. Smith, of Redvers, has disappeared into the municipality of the town. No news of Percheron stallions has been heard from the States. The prices paid was $2,500 each and the owner was willing to pay such a sum without complaint. Such experience on the part of Mr. Michael D'Arcy, who has been engaged by those who take an interest in improving the breed of horses. The stallions stand 17 hands high.

A Dublin paper makes the following report: "The Duke of Wellington has reported Fenian enemies to this country." Major Edwards of the Fenian Army has been arrested in the house of the Fenian raid in Massachusetts. From the Major's well-known courage and gallantry and with the aid of the Fenian raiders, he will be able to make good his escape.

Artists are causing considerable excitement in mining matters, and it is expected that the new discoveries will come to light soon.

The Hudson's Bay railroad extension from Edmonton to Fort Macleod is a large force of men at work. An excellent road is being constructed, strong and substantial character. The same spirit which has been employed previously. Business is brisk at Fort Macleod and Fort William. The railway is being extended at both places. The recent discovery of gold near Fort Artie is causing considerable excitement in mining matters, and it is expected that the new discoveries will come to light soon.

The Hudson's Bay railroad extension from Edmonton to Fort Macleod is a large force of men at work. An excellent road is being constructed, strong and substantial character. The same spirit which has been employed previously. Business is brisk at Fort Macleod and Fort William. The railway is being extended at both places. The recent discovery of gold near Fort Artie is causing considerable excitement in mining matters, and it is expected that the new discoveries will come to light soon.

CANADIAN

S. Thomasius appointed a paid fire brigade captain.

The newspaper men of Grey and Durham have formed an association.

The contracts for the St. Lawrence Canal improvements have been awarded.

Perthshire has passed a by-law against the sale of grocers and liquor.

Essex County grocers and hotel-keepers will take out licenses under the Grocer Act.

Kitchener hotel-keepers will take out licenses under both the Ontario and Dominion acts.

Gordie Hall, C.S.R. engineer, fell from his engine at Malton Bridge and received very serious injury.

Freight sent from Montreal to Brandon by the railways so far greatly in excess of any former similar period.

The Canadian Pacific railway has just commenced the manufacture of locomotives in their workshops, Montreal.

The storm of wind accompanied by snow which visited Brandon and Montreal has been the most severe experienced for several years.

A lad named Donald, while playing at Brandon, fell off his sled and was run over by a larger one behind, and was killed before anyone knew that he was dead.

AMERICAN

There is further decline in the cotton market.

The amount in the public debt for February was about $2,500,000.

The Cincinnati from Glasgow was destroyed by fire. Loss $2,000.

Who is Perry Davis?

ROSSER AVENUE, BRANDON.

EMERSON CONVENTION

The following Resolutions were Adopted:

Resolved, That the interests of the inhabitants of the Red River Colony, both north and south of the boundary line, are identical; and that all should be treated alike by the Dominion Government.

Resolved, That the Dominions Government should take measures to improve the channel of the Red River to facilitate navigation.

Resolved, That in the event of the Dominion Government not extending the boundaries northward to the 52nd parallel, it will be necessary to make such arrangements as may be made with the proprietors of the land north of the present boundary line, so that the land may be used for the purpose intended.

Resolved, That a committee consisting of Messrs. D. Scott, W. H. Gage, and Mr. Henry Tenant, M. P. P., be appointed to meet at Winnipeg, and report upon the Provincial Government's proposal to extend the boundaries northward.

Resolved, That a committee consisting of Messrs. D. Scott, W. H. Gage, and Mr. Henry Tenant, M. P. P., be appointed to meet at Winnipeg, and report upon the Provincial Government's proposal to extend the boundaries northward.

THE BRANDON WEEKLY MAIL

Traveller's Guide!

RAILROAD TIME TABLES

Canadian Pacific Railway Co.

BRANDON POST OFFICE.

Arrival and Departure of Mills.

TOWN TOPICS

THURSDAY, MAR 6, 1884.

Mr. J. Holman has opened a new store front in the shop next to Mr. Reid's store.

In all about thirty people are now connected with the H.M.S. Primrose.

Twenty Detective police sold bonds of $50 each at the market Monday, $12,000 was raised.

The Treasury Board Teachers' Association met at Hopkin City last night and discussed matters.

An auction sale last week raised $3,000, $250, $225, $200 respectively.

Mr. Comstock reached the city Friday morning, accompanied by Mr. Reid and his family.

Mr. Reid is getting his new photographic gallery facilities on Ross Avenue, with commodious display rooms.

Mr. J. R. Hoag, of Milford, was entertained to supper the other evening at Mr. Reid's previous to his departure for England.

Mr. H. T. Smith, traveller for Smith & Sons, visited the city Saturday, and will be here again during the spring.

Mr. F. A. Melchiori is about to open a new store on Ross Avenue, below Reid's, which is to be re-opened shortly.

He will get things in good shape before opening.

Two 12th street print heads an article in the "Weekly Mail" about the Union can live and prosper.

Chief Justice Wallbridge is to do evening address in a resort in end of this month.

Mr. Jackson has been re-elected M.P.P. by Rockwood by a majority of 1,000 votes.

Mr. Neill, alleged to have been in the recent thefts, has been honorably acquitted by the coroner's jury.

There is a great deal of talk about the house in his house, but no one can go to prove he had any knowledge that the goods were stolen.

Mr. McDonald, W. J. Sherwood, and Alex. Reid, for a bit of amuse- ment, were taxed a V each the other day.

On Tuesday evening next, the Brandon city hall will give a concert featuring Mr. Thompson on the piano.

In all some forty prizes will be competed for, making it a most interesting one.

As the band are now sustaining themselves by playing at various places, the public ought to encourage the boys with a show of attention.

Mr. Atkinson is receiving his shipments of spring goods, and will have a large selection of articles in our next issue.

At the general election the Charter party will be identifying itself with property of people residing within ten miles of the city limits.

Our machines men are fitting themselves for the spring trade, and several of them have made some improvements.

Messrs. Sorenson & Johnston are undertaking spring goods at a great rate these days, and will make new selections from the best.

The plowing mill which had been shut down for several weeks was reopened yesterday at full speed.

The large tent was erected ahead.

Mr. Robison and Ethel Robison were visiting the Reid's keep- ing a "house," the other day, but as the weather was conflicting, they kept acquitted.

A large number of the citizens at- tended the annual town entertain- ment on Friday evening last.

The entertainment was most enjoyable in every respect.

Mr. Bennett, going to his stable the other night, found a stranger there, so he called the police.

It is not improbable there are thieves abroad, and the public ought to be on the alert.

The grill will reopen today and will be attended by Mr. Smith, who has been away on the pop.

The Farmers' Union is exhaust-
